Posts.Content: Hi Sally I had a lumpectomy in Dec (week before Christmas) and then a further lump removed in Feb and then as there were no clear margins, I am now recovering from a mastectomy and immediate reconstruction. I was told originally I wouldn't need Chemo, just radiotherapy but now I have had a mastectomy I am hopeful I won't need either; get my results next week. Depending on the grade of cancer and margins, you may not need Chemo so don't worry unnecessarily. I was in hospital with 3 other ladies from the same town and screening session and although we all had the same op, we all had different results so no-one can tell you exactly what will happen.. I find the best way to deal with this is to speak about it openly and your friends will help you through it. Don't bottle things up. It is easier for your friends to help you if you are open and then they don't feel awkward. Remember a trouble shared is a trouble halved.    Pauline x

Posts.Title: Is a massage dangerous?

Posts.Content: For an update on this thread, I have received the following e-mail from my Breast Care Nurse:....................... We would advise avoiding the operated area but would not advise against having massage elsewhere. I’m not sure what they are talking about in terms of “dormant cells”. The Cancer Research UK website has information on massage and they say there is no evidence for this theory. It might be worth printing this off for them. If you wish, tell them that your cancer was lymph node negative and we would not counsel against massage. Certainly facial/ head massage would not be any issue at all. I think they are being extremely over cautious. My colleague in the Maggie’s Centre is doing some more research on your behalf and I will pass on anything she finds. I’m not sure of their rationale as massage is frequently available at Cancer Help Centres and in hospices as part of regular complementary therapies. If you let them know that the hospital does not advise against massage for someone in your situation, with the proviso of avoiding recently operated areas, then I don’t see why they shouldn’t provide the service.   .... I am now going to e-mail Bannatynes with the above e-mail to see what they now say rather than just speak to the receptionist. Watch this space!!   Pauline

Posts.Content: Hi Debra I had a mastectomy and reconstruction done on the same day. 15th March 2011. I have gone back to work this week (4 weeks later) I was driving after 2 weeks. As long as you are in no pain and the seatbelt doesn't rub or uncomfortable, it is ok. I am pleased with my reconstruction although part of it (away from the blood supply) is still quite hard. My surgeon says it will take up to 6 months to settle down properly. My reconstruction was done from my tummy but I am only 7 and a bit stone anyway so my tummy is now tight like a drum; there has got to be some advantages of going through all this.   Take care   Pauline xx

Posts.Content: Hi Gillian I definitely think positive thinking  and getting back to normal as soon as possible, helps the recovery process. I try to think of it as an interuption rather than an illness.  I had a lumpectomy the Monday before Christmas which really annoyed me as I had to miss the works Christmas Party. Arranged to go back to work 3 weeks later and advised there was no clear margins so had to have another lumpectomy. Went back to work finally and then told still no clear margins so would have to have mastectomy. I knew straight away I wanted a reconstruction although my surgeon said some changed their mind because of all what they go through. Any way had the mastectomy and reconstruction but waiting now for an appointment with the oncologist as I may need Chemo as tumour was 40mm and I only have small breasts. I am surprised you say your lump was only 4.5 cm and not 5cm as there is not much difference. Positive thinking and good friends around is the way to go. I talk openly at work about it so no-one feels awkward mentioning it and even joke about it.   I feel that I am one of the lucky ones as it was found before it got too bad; some aren't as lucky.   Love Pauline xx
